headline.main: Contraception Debate Drowns Out Budget Talk

docs.abstract: The new White House chief of staff, Jacob J. Lew, made the rounds of the Sunday television talk shows to discuss President Obama's new budget to be released on Monday, but instead he was forced repeatedly to defend the administration's effort to guarantee that insurers cover birth control for women, in the face of criticism from religious groups.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - The new White House chief of staff, Jacob J. Lew, made the rounds of the Sunday talk shows to discuss the budget that President Obama is to release on Monday, but instead he was forced repeatedly to defend the administration's effort to guarantee that insurers cover birth control for women in the face of criticism from religious groups.

docs.lead_paragraph: The government safety net was created to keep Americans from abject poverty, but the poorest households no longer receive a majority of government benefits.

headline.main: Even Critics of Safety Net Increasingly Depend on It
headline.print_headline: Even Critics of Safety Net Increasingly Depend on It

docs.abstract: Government safety net was created to keep Americans from abject poverty, but the secondary mission of maintaining the middle class from childhood through retirement has now become the priority, with the poorest households no longer receiving a majority of government benefits; many of the loudest critics of the government safety net are in fact recipients of government aid, which has left many of them conflicted about the proper role of government.
docs.snippet: The government safety net was created to keep Americans from abject poverty, but the poorest households no longer receive a majority of government benefits.

byline.original: By BINYAMIN APPELBAUM and ROBERT GEBELOFF

docs.lead_paragraph: For two decades, politicians have promised to make the tax code simpler and fairer, but this time they have a deadline of sorts, with the scheduled expiration of tax cuts.

headline.seo: Tax Code Faces Another Year of Reckoning

docs.abstract: Politicians have promised to make the tax code simpler and fairer for two decades, but this time they have a deadline of sorts, with the scheduled expiration of tax cuts in January 2013; Republicans emphasize expanding the base of income-tax payers, not hitting current taxpayers harder; Democrats want to preserve the progressivity of the tax code, ensuring that the rich pay larger share of the total tax bill and that the poor and middle class pay no more; so far, road to a simpler system has no clear direction.
docs.snippet: For two decades, politicians have promised to make the tax code simpler and fairer, but this time they have a deadline of sorts, with the scheduled expiration of tax cuts.

docs.lead_paragraph: For those who can make sense of the explosion of data, there are job opportunities in fields as diverse as crime, retail and dating.

headline.seo: Big Data’s Impact in the World

docs.abstract: News analysis; data analysts are in high demand due to the abundance of information that is being collected and used, and a concurrent drift toward data-driven discovery and decision-making in a variety of different fields.
docs.snippet: For those who can make sense of the explosion of data, there are job opportunities in fields as diverse as crime, retail and dating.

docs.lead_paragraph: In their beef with President Obama over birth control, Catholic bishops ignore the link between contraceptives and poverty.
docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column questions asserts that what is lost in the controversy over the rule that requires religiously affiliated institutions to provide birth control as part of their health insurance plans is that birth control is central to efforts to chip away at poverty; argues that although it is a basic principle of American life that religious beliefs must be respected, it is only imperative to accommodate those beliefs when possible.
docs.snippet: In their beef with President Obama over birth control, Catholic bishops ignore the link between contraceptives and poverty.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops said a compromise offered by President Obama on birth control coverage did not go far enough in protecting religious liberty.

headline.main: Bishops Reject White House’s New Plan on Contraception
headline.print_headline: Catholic Bishops Reject New Plan on Contraception

docs.abstract: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops rejects Pres Obama's compromise on birth control coverage, saying it does not go far enough in protecting religious liberty; group faces a potential rift with some allies who welcomed the compromise, which puts the onus of providing free contraceptives on health insurance companies rather than the Catholic institutions themselves.
docs.snippet: The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops said a compromise offered by President Obama on birth control coverage did not go far enough in protecting religious liberty.

docs.lead_paragraph: The coal-fired State Line Power Station, on the Illinois-Indiana border, is closing in March. That is bad news for its employees and the local economy, and raises questions about pollution’s effects.

headline.seo: Closing of State Line Power Station, on Illinois-Indiana Border, Is Expected to Leave Problems Behind
headline.main: Power Station’s Closing Could Create Problems
headline.print_headline: Power Station’s Closing Could Create Problems

docs.lead_paragraph: Charles Murray argues that the white working class is no longer a virtuous silent majority.

headline.seo: Charles Murray Examines the White Working Class in ‘Coming Apart’

docs.abstract: Nicholas Confessore reviews book Coming Apart: The State of White America, 1960-2010 by Charles Murray.

docs.lead_paragraph: Asian-Americans, some of them newly minted basketball fans, gathered Friday at Gatsby’s bar to watch Jeremy Lin’s performance.

headline.seo: At SoHo Bar, Jeremy Lin’s Fans Share His Heritage
headline.main: Sharing a Heritage With a New Knicks Star
headline.print_headline: At SoHo Bar, A New Star’s Fans Share His Heritage

docs.abstract: Asian-American New Yorkers, some of them newly minted basketball fans, congregate at a Manhattan sports bar to cheer on New York Knicks sensation Jeremy Lin, one of the few Asian-Americans in NBA history who has come seemingly out of nowhere to champion a Knicks win streak.
docs.snippet: Asian-Americans, some of them newly minted basketball fans, gathered Friday at Gatsby’s bar to watch Jeremy Lin’s performance.
